natural problem: How many positive integers less than $500$ can be written as the sum of two positive perfect cubes?
natural solution: Note that $7^3 < 500 < 8^3,$ so any positive integer that can be written as the sum of two positive perfect cubes must be written as the sum of two cubes $a^3 + b^3$ where $1 \le a \le 7$ and $1 \le b \le 7.$ We can make a chart of the sum of two such cubes: $$
5^3 & & & & & 250 & 341 & 468 \\ 6^3 & & & & & & 432 & {559} \\ 7^3 & & & & & & & {686} \end{array} $$ As we can see from the chart, there are $\boxed{26}$ such numbers less than $500.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat and f :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> (a, b). f (a, b) = a^3 + b^3"
and h1 : "{f (a, b) | a b. a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> f (a, b) < 500} = {n. \<exists> a b. a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> f (a, b) = n \<and> n < 500}"
shows  "card {n. \<exists> a b. a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> f (a, b) = n \<and> n < 500} = 26"

a_1.formal problem:

assumes h0 : "positive_integers = {x. x > 0 \<and> x < 500}"

and h2 : "card {b. b \<in> positive_integers \<and> (\<exists> a. a = b)} = 26"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> positive_integers \<and> (\<exists> a b. x = a^3 + b^3 \<and> a > 0 \<and> b > 0)} = 26"

a_2.formal problem:

 How many positive integers less than $500$ can be written as the sum of two positive perfect cubes? The final Answer is 26
 ### Proof

 *)

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a > 0 \<and> b > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a + b < 500 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> m n. a = m^3 \<and> b = n^3)"
shows  "card {x. \<exists> a b. a + b = x \<and> a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> a + b < 500 \<and> (\<exists> m n. a = m^3 \<and> b = n^3)} = 26"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive integers less than $500$ can be written as the sum of two positive perfect cubes? The final Answer is 26
 ### Proof
 Note that $7^3 < 500 < 8^3,$ so any positive integer that can be written as the sum of two positive perfect cubes must be written as the sum of two cubes $a^3 + b^3$ where $1 \le a \le 7$ and $1 \le b \le 7.$ We can make a chart of the sum of two such cubes: $$
 \begin{array}{c|ccccccc} & 1^3 & 2^3 & 3^3 & 4^3 & 5^3 & 6^3 & 7^3 \\ \hline 1^3 & 2 & 9 & 28 & 65 & 126 & 217 & 344 \\ 2^3 & & 16 & 35 & 72 & 133 & 224 & 351 \\ 3^3 & & & 54 & 91 & 152 & 243 & 370 \\ 4^3 & & & & 128 & 189 & 280 & 407 \\
 5^3 & & & & & 250 & 341 & 468 \\ 6^3 & & & & & & 432 & {559} \\ 7^3 & & & & & & & {686} \end{array} $$ As we can see from the chart, there are $\boxed{26}$ such numbers less than $500.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a > 0 \<and> b > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a + b < 500 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> m n. a = m^3 \<and> b = n^3)"
shows  "card {x. \<exists> a b. a + b = x \<and> a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> a + b < 500 \<and> (\<exists> m n. a = m^3 \<and> b = n^3)} = 26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many positive integer values of $x$ are there such that $x = a + b$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive integers less than 500 and can be expressed as the sum of two perfect cubes (i.e., $a = m^3$ and $b = n^3$ for some integers $m$ and $n$)? The final answer is 26.
